title: Understanding AI Limitations
subtitle: How Tokenization and Training Shape AI Capabilities

slides.title: Understanding Large Language Models in AI (LLMs)
slides.introText: AI gets things wrong, we need to understand why
bulletPoints: A Norwegian man named Arve Hjalmar Holmen asked ChatGPT about himself
The AI fabricated a tragic story about his "sons drowning in a pond"
This completely fictional narrative was presented as fact
How do these "hallucinations" occur in AI systems?
Understanding the inner workings helps us use AI more wisely

slides.title: The Problem of AI Hallucinations
slides.introText: Despite impressive capabilities, AI systems can generate false information with confidence:
bulletPoints: AI systems like ChatGPT can generate false information with confidence
AI relies on the input query and goes through many calculations
The Calculations are hidden from the user, it just a 'Black Box'
By the end of this session I hope you have a better understanding of how AI works
Computers only work with numbers, so AI must convert language into numbers
I hope to explain this topic in a way that is easy to understand, stop me if you want a slower pace

slides.title: The Enormous Corpus Behind AI
bulletPoints: Modern AI is trained on vast amounts of text data
This includes books, websites, scientific papers, and more
The corpus provides patterns for the AI to learn from
But the sheer diversity means the AI must generalize
The scale of data creates challenges for quality control

slides.title: Building the Dictionary: Tokens and Embeddings
bulletPoints: AI breaks language into basic units called "tokens"
Tokens can be words, parts of words, or punctuation
Each token is converted to a unique ID in a dictionary
These IDs map to "embedding vectors" - points in a high-dimensional space
Similar words have embedding vectors that are close together

slides.title: How AI Generates Text
bulletPoints: AI predicts the next token based on previous tokens, using a statistical sampling method
For each prediction, it calculates probabilities for all tokens
It uses sampling strategies to select the next token:
Text is built token by token through this process
subBulletPoints: Weighted Tombola: Tokens with higher probabilities have more "tickets"
Top-K: Only consider K most likely tokens
Top-P: Include enough tokens to reach P% of total probability

slides.title: From Raw Corpus to Training: How AI Learns
bulletPoints: Pre-training phase: Predict next token in sequences
For example: "The capital of France is ___"
Model continuously adjusts its parameters based on errors
Learns through billions of examples and iterations
Uses gradient descent to improve predictions over time
Captures not just vocabulary but grammar, facts, reasoning

slides.title: The Alignment Challenge
bulletPoints: A model trained only to predict the next token isn't naturally helpful
Raw models may generate toxic, biased, or harmful content
Fine-tuning with human feedback addresses these issues:
Balancing multiple objectives: helpfulness, harmlessness, honesty
subBulletPoints: Instruction tuning: Training on helpful prompt-response pairs
Human evaluators rate responses to guide improvement

slides.title: The Journey to a Question-Answering System
bulletPoints: AI doesn't look up answers in a database
It retrieves information encoded in its parameters
For example, asking "Who wrote Romeo and Juliet?":
Answers are generated token by token
Modern systems use techniques like:
subBulletPoints: AI doesn't search a database entry
It recalls that "Shakespeare" frequently appeared near "wrote" and "Romeo and Juliet"
The model generates a response based on these learned associations
